⚡️ The best TV shows of 2022 so far (and where to stream them) https://t.co/fuGoqCN8NJ

Check out the full list here ⬇️
https://t.co/EQyDjztCKz

Conversations With Friends (Amazon Prime Video) is an adaptation of Sally Rooney’s first novel. The series asks the question: What do you do with desires and impulses you don’t understand? It is so slow burning that the delicacy of it is exquisite.
https://t.co/EQyDjztCKz https://t.co/pESJvXuRvS

Shoresy (Crave) is diabolically funny. The spinoff from Letterkenny has the famously foul-mouthed, chirping Shoresy join a senior Triple A hockey team in Sudbury, Ont. It is bonkers, but a beautiful thing. 
https://t.co/EQyDjztCKz https://t.co/XFqTLEHYq0

The much-binged Inventing Anna (Netflix) dramatizes the bizarre story of Anna Delvey, who conned her way upward in New York social circles. By turns schlocky and insightful, it heralded a slew of docudramas about criminals and grifters.
https://t.co/EQyDjztCKz https://t.co/tFPLth4SJs

The Porter (CBC Gem) delivered an eight-episode series teeming with compelling characters set in 1920′s Montreal. Less a history lesson than dramatized interpretation of real events, it’s a sizzling, sexy story about people you want to root for and follow.
https://t.co/EQyDjztCKz https://t.co/lPKasrtl64

Severance (Apple TV+) is about work-life balance, but the approach is only occasionally funny, in a wry, sinister way. In fact, the show is drenched in paranoia about what corporate work does to people.
https://t.co/EQyDjztCKz https://t.co/hxLiQRXtGq

Looking for something new to watch tonight? We have you covered. Here are the best TV shows of 2022 so far, and where to stream them:

⚡️ As Russians advance in eastern Ukraine, city of Slovyansk fears the horrors of 2014 will return https://t.co/URr1ld4nrR

The Globe's @markmackinnon reports from Slovyansk to see what might happen if history repeats itself. 

Read the full story here⬇️
https://t.co/5xpqkCDdRB

Slovyansk is expected to be the next major target if and when Russia captures the besieged cities of Sieverodonetsk and Lysychansk, 70 kilometres to the east.
https://t.co/5xpqkCDdRB https://t.co/SKsnR1vOml

Donbas is once more the main front in the war. And Slovyansk, a city of just over 100,000 people that is still dealing with the trauma of eight years ago, is once more in Russia’s crosshairs.
https://t.co/5xpqkCDdRB https://t.co/KuaGl1QrQA

Now that awful history is repeating. The early weeks of the war were marked by rapid Russian advances toward the capital of Kyiv, then a retreat that let the world see the atrocities committed in the places that fell under Russian occupation.
https://t.co/5xpqkCDdRB https://t.co/AuuJuhQVki

After Slovyansk was liberated by the Ukrainian army that July, Yukov and the Black Tulips dug up the mass graves left behind. He estimates there were some 200 corpses, including many who bore signs of torture, just as in Bucha eight years later.
https://t.co/5xpqkCDdRB https://t.co/T9U8cIpL1A

Yukov’s life was spared by the last-minute intervention of a senior pro-Russian official, who appreciated the work Yukov and his Black Tulips organization did and do – collecting the dead on both sides of the conflict.
https://t.co/5xpqkCDdRB

In 2014, Yukov was almost a very early casualty of the smaller-scale conflict that preceded Russia’s full-blown invasion of Ukraine this year. He was imprisoned in a basement and an order for his execution was signed.
https://t.co/5xpqkCDdRB

Driving around his native Donbas region, collecting the bodies of dead civilians and soldiers – and with the Russian army closing on his hometown of Slovyansk – Oleksiy Yukov can’t believe it’s all happening again.
https://t.co/5xpqkCDdRB https://t.co/kWvp2SCZfI
